description: Borrowed from Latin salūtō (“to greet; to wish health to”), from salūs (“greeting, good health”), related to salvus (“safe”).

entries.meaning: An utterance or gesture expressing greeting or honor towards someone, now especially a formal, non-verbal gesture made with the arms or hands in any of various specific positions. [from 15th c.]
examples: The soldiers greeted the dignitaries with a crisp salute.

entries.meaning: A kiss, offered in salutation. [from 16th c.]
examples: [M]aking an apology which, not suspecting his intention, I did not understand, – he gave me a most ardent salute! I have seldom been more surprised. I had no idea of his taking such a freedom.

entries.meaning: (military, nautical) A discharge of cannon or similar arms, as a mark of honour or respect. [from 17th c.]
A pyrotechnic device primarily designed to produce a loud bang.

verbs.description: salute (third-person singular simple present salutes, present participle saluting, simple past and past participle saluted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To make a gesture in honor of (someone or something).
examples: They saluted the flag as it passed in the parade.

entries.meaning: To act in thanks, honor, or tribute; to thank or extend gratitude; to praise.
examples: I would like to salute the many dedicated volunteers that make this project possible.

entries.meaning: (Ireland, informal) to wave, to acknowledge an acquaintance.
examples: I saluted Bill at the concert, but he didn't see me through the crowd.

entries.meaning: To address, as with expressions of kind wishes and courtesy; to greet; to hail.
examples: He was saluted by Mr. James Hall, with these words: “Well, brother chip! How many murders have you been committing?”

entries.meaning: To promote the welfare and safety of; to benefit; to gratify.
